In the popular eye, American college students over the
years have beconie a'symbol of irresponsibility. Student antics
have been an international phenomenon for a long while, whether
they take the form of pipe smoking, beard growing or drinking
contests, or just healthy mass riots. But there seems to be a
national aversion to recognizing any but the lighter side of
collegiate life:
For this reason we were pleased to notice the national
recognition given to the recent controversy about debating the
affirmative side of the question "Should the 'United States Recognize Red China." For although the mere questioning of the right
to discuss this topic implies a misunderstanding of the idea behind
collegiate debating and a disregard of the First Amendment,
it at least has brought to public attention the college student's
awareness of serious issues. •
It has been repOrted by the press that a Virginia Representative to the United States Congress attempted to influence a
student so that the student would refrain from debating the affirmative side of the national debating topic for this year. This is
not only a flagrant violation of personal rights, but also another
of the many attempts to limit the sphere of free intellectual
inquiry..
Officials of the Army and Navy have forbidden the debating
teams of West Point and Annapolis to take up the subject,
contending that it is not befitting a potential officer to argue in
contradiction of State Department Policy. This is to suggest that
it is improper for a potential officer (and a great number of
college students are) to disagree with that nebulous, vascillating
entity termed State Department Policy. This is a threat to free
expression.
The encouraging aspect of the issue is that an overwhelming
majority of college officials, and even President Eisenhower,
have given their approval to the proposed topic, an encouraging
sign to those concerned about the threatened loss of academic
freedom. Perhaps more important is the evidence that the
American college student has both the courage and seriousness
to be outspoken when he feels his rights curtailed.
It is with relief that we note that Dean Shaffer has givea his
support to the proposed topic of debate. It is no less reassuring
that this weekend the Homewood campus\will be the scene of an
intercollegiate conference on Southeast Asia where students will
be able to discuss without fear whatever topics their curiosity shall
lead them to.

In the popular eye, American college students over the
years have beconie a'symbol of irresponsibility. Student antics
have been an international phenomenon for a long while, whether
they take the form of pipe smoking, beard growing or drinking
contests, or just healthy mass riots. But there seems to be a
national aversion to recognizing any but the lighter side of
collegiate life:
For this reason we were pleased to notice the national
recognition given to the recent controversy about debating the
affirmative side of the question "Should the 'United States Recognize Red China." For although the mere questioning of the right
to discuss this topic implies a misunderstanding of the idea behind
collegiate debating and a disregard of the First Amendment,
it at least has brought to public attention the college student's
awareness of serious issues. •
It has been repOrted by the press that a Virginia Representative to the United States Congress attempted to influence a
student so that the student would refrain from debating the affirmative side of the national debating topic for this year. This is
not only a flagrant violation of personal rights, but also another
of the many attempts to limit the sphere of free intellectual
inquiry..
Officials of the Army and Navy have forbidden the debating
teams of West Point and Annapolis to take up the subject,
contending that it is not befitting a potential officer to argue in
contradiction of State Department Policy. This is to suggest that
it is improper for a potential officer (and a great number of
college students are) to disagree with that nebulous, vascillating
entity termed State Department Policy. This is a threat to free
expression.
The encouraging aspect of the issue is that an overwhelming
majority of college officials, and even President Eisenhower,
have given their approval to the proposed topic, an encouraging
sign to those concerned about the threatened loss of academic
freedom. Perhaps more important is the evidence that the
